newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries open unchanged, tight ranges seen.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries open unchanged, tight ranges seen.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries opened largely unchanged on Monday, with the market expected to stick to narrow ranges amid a dearth of economic news.
Activity is expected to be very light, as the combination of no data and the start of the Passover holiday at sundown is seen keeping most players on the sidelines.

"People are going to be trying to leave early so I imagine we don't do a heck of a lot," said a head trader at a primary dealership. "The only catalyst that could move us is if the dollar weakens more."
In early trading, the 30-year bond was unchanged at 94-22/32 to yield 7.05 percent.
Treasuries had been a bit weaker in the Tokyo and London session during the night, as the dollar came under pressure. Market participants reported light selling overseas in two- and five-year notes.

But the market is said to be lacking direction. Treasuries, for the most part, rallied last week as bond-bullish economic news triggered waves of short-covering, bringing yields down to levels not seen since right after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in late March.
Given that the market did so well last week, market participants are unsure what the next trade will be.
"We're still in a rate rising mode, so we can't rally forever," said the trader. "Most people have a short bias. We have to squeeze everyone out."
Since there are still shorts that may still need to be covered, which could spark another mini-rally.
Yet, the market faces a challenge the next two days in the way of supply. On Tuesday, the Treasury will sell $17 billion of two-year notes, followed by $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday.

LaVorgna, like mamy others, believes the 30-year bond is locked in a 7.00 to 7.25 percent range for the time being. So, since the bond is at the lower end of that range, "the market is ripe for a tape bomb," in which the market could get caught off guard by hawkish comments from Fed officials.

The lone piece of data on this session's schedule is the March federal budget figure, due at 1400 EDT/1800 GMT. The deficit is seen falling to $30.7 billion, from a $44.01 billion deficit in the prior report, according to a Reuters poll.
Many agreed that the current levels of 6.42 percent on the when-issued two-year note and 6.72 percent on the when-issued five-year note are too expensive, which, in turn, could push the market down.

"We're now near the highs of the last couple weeks, and given the fact we had a runup last week, it certainly seems that there would be concessions," said Joe Lavorgna, financial market economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "We are still in a bear market. A lot of people are making the bet that the Fed goes another 50 basis points in the next eight months, which keeps the market under pressure in the short term."
Also, Fed vice chair Alice Rivlin is slated to speak at the Employment Policy Foundation's wage and productvity forum in Washington D.C. at 1300 EDT/1700 GMT.
Meanwhile, the three-month bill was up one basis point at 5.16 percent, while the six-month and year-bills were unchanged at 5.40 percent and 5.59 percent, respectively.
Two-year notes were unchanged at 99-24/32, yielding 6.39 percent. Five-year notes were up 1/32 at 99-21/32 to yield 6.71 percent, and 10-year notes were up 1/32 at 95-30/32, yielding 6.82 percent.
